name: Heptadecanoic acid
Reason: The base structure for heptadecanoic acid is the hydrocarbon chain with 17 carbon atoms, which in the form of an alkane (heptadecane) has a melting point of about 22°C. Adding a carboxyl group (COOH) typically raises the melting point due to the possibility of hydrogen bonding, which increases intermolecular forces. The carboxyl group can increase the melting point by roughly 40°C. Since the long hydrocarbon chain also allows for greater Van der Waals forces, we can take into account an increase of about 1°C per additional CH2 group compared to the base structure (which is already counted in the 22°C for heptadecane).
